title: Sumerians – Dynasties of Kish (Part II)

maps.text: Part of map of Asia highlighting the region from Mesopotamia to the Zagros Mountains in Iran, representing the areas occupied by the ancient Sumerians (<a href="#" onclick="htCleanSources(); htFillReferenceSource('5be12554-c54b-4a38-b24c-5a0842fdfd9d'); return false;">Kessler, P. L., <htdate0>). The area is marked approximately to provide the reader with a clearer visualization

common.text:
Ancient texts

Due to the frequent confusion with the literal interpretation of the Mesopotamian flood, we wrote a serie of four texts to help readers to undertstand what ancient authors were describing:

  • (Texts with Sciences (Part I)): we study the concepts of "world" and "sky" in Mesopotamian cultures and how the lack of understanding of the surrounding environment may have led to the idea of an extraordinarily long lifespan, incompatible with human nature.
  • (Texts with Sciences (Part II)): we explore the water cycle and the law of conservation of mass. With this, we discussed how the concept of "world" in Mesopotamia differs from our own.
  • (Texts with Sciences (Part III)): we examined the epics of Gilgamesh and Atrahasis, as well as the Sumerian deluge narratives. Within them, we identified a recurring narrative pattern: a few people and animals are saved in a boat, described in various shapes (cubic or circular), following a divine punishment. From this, we established the probable periods in which these deluges occurred and compared them with data from other regions, concluding that there were no global floods.
  • (Texts with Sciences (Conclusion)): we concluded our study with an analysis of two different papers that mapped floods across the world at various times, providing context for the conditions under which Mediterranean authors wrote their texts.
Figura 2: Sumerian King List. © Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford (Ashmolean Image Library).

prerequisites: This text is a continuation of the first text published about the Kings of Kish on History Tracers. Therefore, we suggest studying it before continuing (Sumerians - Dynasties of Kish).

history.text:
In this text, we will address the second group of people that appears in the Sumerian King List associated with Kish. Unlike the first part, where the existence of a king, Enmebaragesi, was verified through an inscription found on a vase (<htcite0>; <htcite1>; <htcite2>; <htcite3>), nothing has yet been found about any of the individuals to be cited in this text.

Given this scenario, we will use this text to engage in reflections and reinforce the understanding of mathematics.
They are mentioned in the Sumerian King List as having ruled for 201 years (<htcite0>; <htcite1>).

Reflection 2: The same age as...

How many people do you know today who worked for 210 years before retiring?

Would it be possible for someone to still perform any activity at that age?

Do you know anyone who has lived for more than two centuries?

Since the character Dadasig, mentioned in this text, has no indicated relationship with the supposed previous king, Susuda, in the Sumerian King List (<htcite0>; <htcite1>), we chose not to work with them together. Thus, as a precaution, we preferred to create a separate entry.
He is mentioned in the Sumerian King List as having ruled for 81 years (<htcite0>; <htcite1>).

Reflection 3: Now with two...

Could two kings, on average, rule for 141 years each?

Do you find it more acceptable for someone to rule for 141 years than for 201 years?
Let's understand where we got the value 141 for the question. First, we add the 201 years of Susuda's reign with the 81 years of Dadasig:

201
+  81
____________
  282

Calculation 1: Sum of the supposed reign periods of the two kings.

After obtaining the total through **Calculation 1**, we performed an arithmetic mean (<htcite0>), to find out how long, on average, the two kings ruled. This calculation is done by dividing the total number of years mentioned by the number of kings who ruled. In our study, we divided 282 by 2 (<htcite1>):

282 2
- 200 141
    82  
-   80  
      2  
-     2  
      0  

Calculation 2: Division of 282 by 2.

Since arithmetic means can cause confusion, we detail what was done in **Calculations 1 and 2**:
- We measured the total ruling time by adding the first period (201 years) with the second period (81 years), according to **Calculation 1**.
- Then, we estimated how those years would be distributed between two kings (**Calculation 2**) obtaining an average value.
- Note that the average value does not change the original values.
- An average also does not need to result necessarily in one of the summed values.
- No king, in fact, would have ruled for 141 years; however, this is a central value between the supposed reigns.

We conclude this reflection by indicating that this central value, that is, 141, is at the same distance from 201 and from 81 (<htcite0>):

201             141
-   141            - 81
_____        _____
      60              60

Calculation 3: Distance of the reign values in relation to their average.
The kings listed in this section are said to be father and son (<htcite0>; <htcite1>), despite neither king having been proven.
He is mentioned in the Sumerian King List as having ruled for 360 years (<htcite0>; <htcite1>).
Because there is a mention of paternity for Mamagal, it was added in this text. However, since there is no concrete proof, we also treat it as hypothetical.
There is no proof of their existence beyond a later mention in the Sumerian King List (<htcite0>; <htcite1>); therefore, we treat the relationship as hypothetical.
Nothing else has been found about him apart from his supposed reign of 195 years, mentioned in the *Sumerian King List* (<htcite0>; <htcite1>). Therefore, we propose another reflection:

Reflection 4: Greater or Lesser

The reign years of the supposed kings in this section (Mamagal and Kalbum) are greater than the reign years of the two previous supposed kings (Susuda and Dadasig).

Is the average number of years for these two kings greater or lesser than that of the others?
To answer this reflection as best as possible, we will once again calculate the average between the two kings in this section. We begin, once more, by adding the supposed reign years:

1 
  360
+ 195
____________
  555

Calculation 4: Sum of the supposed reign period of the two kings.

Recall that the arithmetic mean of the years reigned is obtained by summing the reign years of the rulers and dividing by the number of rulers. Therefore, the arithmetic mean of the 555 years for two rulers is given by:

555 2
- 400 277
  155  
- 140  
    15  
-   14 
      1  

Calculation 5: Division of 555 by 2.

**Calculation 5** shows us that the result of the division is 277, with a remainder of 1. At this point, we will stop here, as the result aligns with what has already been taught in *History Tracers*, in the *First Steps* (<htcite0>). As knowledge advances in that section, the text will be rewritten.

From **Calculations 4 and 5**, we can conclude that the average of the supposed years reigned by these last two kings (277) is greater than that of the previous kings (141).
The kings listed in this section are also said to be father and son (<htcite0>; <htcite1>), although neither king has been proven to exist.

He is mentioned in the *Sumerian King List* as having reigned for 360 years (<htcite0>; <htcite1>). We draw attention to the fact that this period is the same as that reported in the list for Mamagal.

Reflection 5: Understanding the Average

To find the average number of years per ruler, we add the reign periods and divide by the number of rulers. We have performed this operation twice already; now it is your turn.

What is the average number of years reigned by Tuge?

If this reflection seemed confusing at first, you may not yet have understood what an average is. That's okay; let's analyze this case together.

When we had two people to calculate the average for, we added their years of reign and divided by 2. When we have only one person, we use all the years they reigned and divide by 1.

Reflection 6: Seriously?

Is the average number of reign years for a single king equal to the years he reigned?

When referring to the reign years of a single king, we add, year by year, his reign period until we reach the total years he ruled. Since any number divided by 1 is equal to itself (<htcite0>), the average number of years he reigned is exactly equal to the years he reigned. For this reason, we do not usually calculate the average for a single element; however, the fact that we are not in the habit of doing so does not mean it doesn't exist.
Because there is a mention of paternity for Tuge, it has been added to this text. However, as there is no concrete proof, the relationship is also treated as hypothetical.
There is no proof of their existence beyond a late mention in the *Sumerian King List* (<htcite0>; <htcite1>); therefore, we treat the relationship as hypothetical.

He is mentioned in the *Sumerian King List* as having ruled for 180 years (<htcite0>; <htcite1>).

This supposed reign period is half that of his father's period (360 ÷ 2 = 180), which also means the supposed reign period of his father is twice his (180 × 2 = 360).

We will not explicitly perform the summation of the period of the two supposed kings this time, but we encourage the reader to do so. The result that should be found in the sum is 540 (360 + 180 = 540). If there is still any doubt about how to perform these operations, we recommend studying Chapter 3 of the *First Steps* section (<htcite2>).

Now, we calculate the average years ruled between the supposed kings:

540 2
- 400 270
  140  
- 140  
      0  

Calculation 6: Division of 540 by 2.

Since the sum of the reign period of these supposed kings (540) is less than the sum of the reign period of Mamagal and Kalbum (555), we obtain an average reign period lower than that of the two previous supposed rulers.

The order of the last two kings of Kish would be altered, with Lugalmu being the only one identified (<htcite0>; <htcite1>). Recent research suggests the eighth king might be named "Ibbi-Ea" (<htcite2>), or "Enbi-Ištar" (<htcite3>). Due to these issues, we anticipate the mention of Lugalmu, considering him the seventh king, but will refer to the eighth as Unknown.
He is mentioned in the *Sumerian King List* as having ruled for 360 years (<htcite0>; <htcite1>).

Not even the name of this king has been fully understood (<htcite0>; <htcite1>; <htcite2>; <htcite3>).

The lack of data about this supposed king allows us to analyze another scenario, in which we will once again use averages.

Looking at the first group of Kish's rulers, we observe that the *Sumerian King List* reports that 23 kings ruled for *"24510 years, 3 months and 3 1/2 days"* (<htcite4>; <htcite5>), which means that, on average, each king ruled for approximately 1,065 years (24.510 ÷ 23 ≈ 1.065).

Regarding the second list of Kish's kings, we are informed that 8 kings ruled for *"3.195 year"* (<htcite6>; <htcite7>), which means each king ruled, on average, 399 years (3.195 ÷ 8 ≈ 399).

Reflection 7: Did it improve?

Is an average reign period of 399 years closer to a normal lifespan than a period of 1,065 years?

Considering the people you live with, is it possible to accept any of these values as real?

Of the 31 kings (23 + 8 = 31), only Enmebaragesi has had his existence proven, and he is said to have ruled for 900 years. Does the proof that he existed also confirm his age?

Despite the large reduction in the average reign period, any average presented in the *Sumerian King List* is much greater than the human lifespan. Even if there is proof of Enmebaragesi's existence, it does not prove his age; it only proves that he existed.
He is mentioned in the Sumerian King List as having ruled for 290 years (<htcite0>; <htcite1>).

exercise_v2.question: Do the non-human ages show there was a better quality of life in the past than today?
exercise_v2.additionalInfo: The centenary—and some even millenary—ages shown in the Sumerian King List indicate a different understanding of time by the Sumerians. There is no way to approximate this information to the real world, especially considering that none of the people mentioned in this text have had their existence fully proven.

exercise_v2.question: Does mathematics help us find potential problems in ancient narratives?
exercise_v2.additionalInfo: When we observe ages different from those seen among human beings, mathematics helps us measure these differences and suspect that, at the very least, the reported age is incorrect. It also helps us verify if a person existed when we compare the date a text was written with the date an object is found. If the object is contemporary to the mentioned people, we can confirm their existence.

exercise_v2.question: Does the fact that Kalbum is mentioned as the son of Mamagal prove that both existed?
exercise_v2.additionalInfo: It is not possible to infer, from a single sentence, that these people actually existed. To prove their existence, archaeological evidence, such as inscriptions, is needed in addition to the text. The familial relationship, as well as the names mentioned in the ancient text, do not constitute sufficient proof.
